translated: Verses of the Elder Monks 16.4
Verses of the Elders🔽.🔽The Twentieth Chapter🔽The First Chapter
Ratthapala
Look at the well-made image,
erected on a base,
sick, with many thoughts,
which has no lasting stability.

analyzed: passa citta katam rūpa  maṇinā kuṇḍalena ca
translated: Look at the well-made form,🔽with jewels and earrings,
bones covered with skin,
shining with clothes.
Feet painted red,
face smeared with powder,
enough to delude a fool,
but not one seeking the other shore.
Hair done in eight-strand braids,
eyebrows smeared with collyrium,
enough to delude a fool,
but not one seeking the other shore.
Like a new painted carriage,
the foul body is adorned,
enough to delude a fool,
but not one seeking the other shore.
The deer sees the snare,
but the deer does not avoid the trap;
having eaten the bait, we will go,
the deer-trapper is crying.
The deer has cut the snare,
but the deer does not avoid the trap;
having eaten the bait, we will go,
the deer-hunter is crying.

original: Passāmi loke sadhane manusse,🔽Laddhāna vittaṁ na dadanti mohā;
analyzed: passāmi loke sa dhane manusse  vittam na dadanti mohā
translated: I see in the world men who are wealthy,🔽Who, through delusion, do not give when they have wealth;
Greedy, they make their hoard of riches,
And long for more and more sensual pleasures.
A king, having conquered the earth with its people,🔽And having dominion over the earth bounded by the ocean,
Being dissatisfied with the land on this side of the ocean,
Would seek the land on the other side of the ocean.

original: Rājā ca aññe ca bahū manussā,
analyzed: rājā ca aññe ca bahū manussā
translated: The king and many other men,
Die with their craving unsatisfied;
Having died, they leave the body behind,
Unsatisfied with sensual pleasures in the world.
His relatives weep and tear their hair,

original: Aho vatā no amarāti cāhu;🔽Vatthena naṁ pārutaṁ nīharitvā,
analyzed: aho vata naḥ ca āhu  vatthena nam pārutam nīharitvā
translated: Saying: “Alas! Our dear one is dead!”🔽Having carried him out wrapped in a cloth,
Having piled up the funeral pyre, they burn him there.
He is burned, being pierced by the flames,
Having left his wealth behind, wrapped in a single cloth;
When he is dying, relatives,

original: Ñātī ca mittā atha vā sahāyā.🔽Dāyādakā tassa dhanaṁ haranti,
analyzed: ñātī ca mittā atha vā sahāyā  dāyādakā tassa dhanam haranti
translated: Friends, or companions are no protection.🔽His heirs take away his wealth,
But the being goes on to where his deeds have taken him.
Wealth does not follow one who dies,

original: Puttā ca dārā ca dhanañca raṭṭhaṁ.
translated: nor children, nor wives, nor wealth, nor the kingdom.
One does not obtain a long life through wealth,

analyzed: na ca api vittena jaram vihanti
translated: nor does wealth ward off old age.

analyzed: appam hi dam jīvitam āhu dhīrā
translated: The wise say that life is short,
impermanent, subject to change.
The rich and the poor experience contact,

original: Bālo ca dhīro ca tatheva phuṭṭho;
analyzed: bālo ca dhīro ca tathā iva phuṭṭhaḥ
translated: and the fool and the wise are touched in the same way.

analyzed: bālaḥ hi bālyā vadhitaḥ uva sā iti
translated: For the fool, being foolish, lies down as if slain,

analyzed: dhīro ca naḥ vedhati phassa phuṭṭhaḥ
translated: but the wise one is not tormented by contact.

analyzed: tasmā hi paññā ava dhanena seyyā
translated: Therefore, wisdom is better than wealth,

analyzed: yāya vosānam idhā adhigacchati  hi bhava abhavesu
translated: by which one attains the end.
For, being unawakened, through delusion one commits evil deeds🔽in this existence and the next.
One goes to the womb and to the other world,
to rebirth in samsara, one after another.
The unwise one, having faith in this,
goes to the womb and to the other world.
Just as a thief caught at the breach
is punished for his own evil deeds,
so in the other world after death,
one is punished for one’s own evil deeds.
Pleasures are varied, sweet, and charming,
But they disturb the mind with their false appearance.
Seeing the danger in the pleasures of the senses,
Therefore, O King, I went forth.
Young men fall down like fruits from trees,

analyzed: daharā ca vuḍḍhā ca sarīra bhedā
translated: The young and the old, their bodies broken.

analyzed: etam pi disvā pabbajitaḥ amhi rāja
translated: Seeing this too, O King, I went forth,
The state of a monk is not in vain, it is better.
I went forth in faith,
Endowed with the Jina’s Dispensation;
My going forth is not in vain,

original: anaṇo bhuñjāmi bhojanaṁ.🔽Kāme ādittato disvā,🔽Jātarūpāni satthato;
analyzed: anaṇaḥ bhuñjāmi bhojana  kāme ādit tatas disvā  jātarūpāni satthataḥ
translated: I eat food without debt.🔽Seeing the pleasures of the senses as burning,🔽Like molten gold,
The suffering of emerging from the womb,
And the great fear in the hells.

analyzed: etam ādīnavam ñatvā  sa vegam alabhim tadā
translated: Knowing this danger,🔽I attained a sense of spiritual urgency then;
Then, being pierced by that, I became peaceful,
And attained the destruction of the pollutants.
The Teacher has been served by me,
The Buddha’s Dispensation has been done;
The heavy burden has been laid down,
The tendency to (re)becoming has been destroyed.
For the sake of which I went forth,🔽From home to the homeless life,
That purpose has been attained by me,
The destruction of all the fetters.”
… the Elder Ratthapala …
